sen.j: 的（まと）は、弓道・弓術で用いる標的である。
sen.e: The term "mato" refers to a target used in kyudo and other Japanese archery arts.
Mato refers to a target used in kyudo and other Japanese archery arts.
Mato refers to a target used in kyudo and other Japanese archery arts.

sen.j: 的の種類・設置法は、現在は正式に全日本弓道連盟の競技規則（以下競技規則と略称する）によって取り決められている。
sen.e: At present the competition rules provided by All Nippon Kyudo Federation (hereinafter referred to as the competition rules) specify the official types of mato and the installation procedures.
At present the competition rules provided by All Nippon Kyudo Federation (hereinafter referred to as the competition rules) specify the official types of mato and the installation procedures.
At present the competition rules provided by All Nippon Kyudo Federation (hereinafter referred to as the competition rules) specify the official types of mato and the installation procedures.

sen.j: 以前は流派・地域・道場によって少々差があり、的も現在より多くの種類があった。
sen.e: The types of mato and their installation procedures somewhat varied depending on schools, regions, and dojo (halls for martial art training) in the past, and there were more types of mato than at present.

The types of mato and their installation procedures somewhat slightly varied depending on schools, regions, and dojo (halls for martial art training) in the past, and there were more types of mato than at present.

The types of mato and their installation procedures somewhat slightly varied depending on schools, regions, and dojo (halls for martial art training) in the past, and there were more types of mato than at present.

sen.j: 現在でも連盟が関与しない場合は競技規則通りとは限らない。
sen.e: Even now they do not always follow the competition rules unless the federation is involved.
Even now they do not always follow the competition rules unless the federation is involved.
Even now they do not always follow the competition rules unless the federation is involved.

sen.j: 近的競技で用いる的は、木製の細長い板を丸めてとめ、輪状にした「的枠」の一方に的紙を貼り付けたものである。
sen.e: A mato used in kinteki (regular close-range shooting) competitions consists of a 'matowaku,' which is a circular frame made by fixing a wooden strip, and a matogami (paper target face) attached on one side of the matowaku.

A mato used in kinteki (regular close-range shooting) competitions consists of a 'matowaku,' which is a circular frame made by fixing a wooden strip, and a matogami (paper target face) attached on one side of the matowaku.

A mato used in kinteki (regular close-range shooting) competitions consists of a 'matowaku,' which is a circular frame made by fixing a wooden strip, and a matogami (paper target face) attached on one side of the matowaku.

sen.j: 木製的枠は狂いや損傷が生じやすく、また板の両端を二重に重ねて綴じた部分（綴じ目）に矢が挟まり抜くのに苦労するし、矢が損傷することもある。
sen.e: A wooden matowaku can easily have a warp and damage, and players have a difficulty in pulling out an arrow which gets stuck in a seam, where both the ends of a wooden strip are fixed; besides, it sometimes hurts arrows.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: A wooden matowaku can easily have a warp and damage, and players have a difficulty in pulling out an arrow which gets stuck in a seam, where both the ends of a wooden strip are fixed; besides, it sometimes hurts the arrows.

A wooden matowaku can easily have a warp and damage, and players have a difficulty in pulling out an arrow which gets stuck in a seam, where both the ends of a wooden strip are fixed; besides, it sometimes hurts the arrows.

sen.j: そのため近年では合板や樹脂製の綴じ目の無いものも販売されている。
sen.e: Therefore matowaku made of plywood and seamless matowaku are also available in recent years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore matowaku made of plywood and seamless matowaku are also available in recent years.
Therefore matowaku made of plywood and seamless matowaku are also available in recent years.

sen.j: 的紙の材質は名の通り紙のものが主流であるが、近年ビニール製のものが開発され、破けにくいなどの利点から学校弓道を中心に急速に普及している。
sen.e: The material of matogami is mainly paper, as its name represents, but vinyl ones have been developed recently and they have rapidly become popular especially in school kyudo because of some advantages such as durability.

The material of matogami is mainly paper, as its name represents, but vinyl ones have been developed recently and they have rapidly become popular especially in school kyudo because of some advantages such as durability.

The material of matogami is mainly paper, as its name represents, but vinyl ones have been developed recently and they have rapidly become popular especially in school kyudo because of some advantages such as durability.

sen.j: 遠的競技で用いる的は、主に台の上に設置した円形の畳に的紙を貼り付けたものを使用する。
sen.e: A typical mato used in enteki (long-distance shooting) competitions is a circular tatami (straw mat) settled on a platform with a matogami attached on it.
A typical mato used in enteki (long-distance shooting) competitions is a circular tatami (straw mat) settled on a platform with a matogami attached on it.
A typical mato used in enteki (long-distance shooting) competitions is a circular tatami (straw mat) settled on a platform with a matogami attached on it.

sen.j: 近的の場合、的は射位（射手が矢を射る位置・体の正中）から28メートル離れた安土上に、中心が（射場の床と水平な）地上27センチメートルで後方に5度 (角度)傾けて設置する。
sen.e: In kinteki, a mato should be placed against an azuchi (target bank) which is 28 meters away from the shai (the position at where a player shoots an arrow, and it should be at the center of the body) at a five-degree angle backward, and its center should be 27 centimeters above the ground (it has to be level with the archery ground).
sen.cmt: 原文には 「5度（角度）」 とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「5度」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: In kinteki, a mato should be placed against an azuchi (target bank) which is 28 meters away from the shai (the position at where a player shoots an arrow, and it should be at the center of the body) at a 5-degree angle backward, and its center should be 27 centimeters above the ground (it has to be level with the archery ground).
sen.cmt: 後述の文章と対比しているため、アラビア数字にしました。
sen.e: In kinteki, a mato should be placed against an azuchi (target bank) which is 28 meters away from the shai (the position at where a player shoots an arrow, and it should be at the center of the body) at a 5-degree angle backward, and its center should be 27 centimeters above the ground (it has to be level with the archery ground).

sen.j: 侯串（こうぐし・ごうぐし）と呼ばれる、さすまた状の串を支えとして安土に固定する。
sen.e: The mato is settled on the azuchi supported by a kogushi (also known as gogushi), a stick in a sasumata (weapon with a U-shaped metal prong attached to the end of a wooden stick) shape.
The mato is settled on the azuchi supported by a kogushi (also known as gogushi), a stick in a sasumata (weapon with a U-shaped metal prong attached to the end of a wooden stick) shape.
The mato is settled on the azuchi supported by a kogushi (also known as gogushi), a stick in a sasumata (weapon with a U-shaped metal prong attached to the end of a wooden stick) shape.

sen.j: 遠的の場合は射位から60メートル離れた所に、中心が地上97cmで後方に15度傾くように設置する。
sen.e: In enteki, a mato is settled at a place which is 60 meters away from the shai at a 15-degree angle backward, and the center of the mato is 97 centimeters above the ground.
In enteki, a mato is settled at a place which is 60 meters away from the shai at a 15-degree angle backward, and the center of the mato is 97 centimeters above the ground.
In enteki, a mato is settled at a place which is 60 meters away from the shai at a 15-degree angle backward, and the center of the mato is 97 centimeters above the ground.

sen.j: 近的競技では一般に直径36cmの的を用いる。
sen.e: A mato which has a diameter of 36 centimeters is commonly used in kinteki competitions.
A mato of 36 centimeters in diameter is commonly used in kinteki competitions.
A mato of 36 centimeters in diameter is commonly used in kinteki competitions.

sen.j: 36cmは伝統的な的の寸法である一尺二寸に相当する。
sen.e: A length of 36 centimeters is equivalent to one shaku (approximately 30.03 centimeters) and two sun (approximately 6.06 centimeters), which are the size of a traditional mato.
A length of 36 centimeters is equivalent to one shaku (approximately 30.03 centimeters) and two sun (approximately 6.06 centimeters), which are the size of a traditional mato.
A length of 36 centimeters is equivalent to one shaku (approximately 30.03 centimeters) and two sun (approximately 6.06 centimeters), which are the size of a traditional mato.

sen.j: 競技規則ではセンチメートル単位で定められているが、「尺二（的）」との呼称も一般的である。
sen.e: Although the competition rules specify the size in a centimeter unit, it is also generally called 'shaku-ni' (or 'shaku-ni mato,' which stands for 'isshaku-nisun,' meaning one shaku and two sun).
Although the competition rules specify the size in a centimeter unit, it is also generally called 'shaku-ni' (also referred as 'shaku-ni mato,' which stands for mato in one shaku and two sun).
Although the competition rules specify the size in a centimeter unit, it is also generally called 'shaku-ni' (also referred as 'shaku-ni mato,' which stands for mato in one shaku and two sun).

sen.j: 順位決定のため射詰競射を行う場合は直径24cm的（八寸に相当。八寸（的）と呼ばれる）が使用されることがある。
sen.e: A mato which has a diameter of 24 centimeters (which is equivalent to eight sun, and this is called hassun or hassun mato, meaning eight sun) is sometimes used in an izume (a competition in which a shooter who misses the target is excluded) game for a tiebreaker.

A mato of 24 centimeters in diameter (which is equivalent to eight sun, and this is called hassun or hassun mato, meaning eight sun) is sometimes used in an izume (a competition in which a shooter who misses the target is excluded) game for a tiebreaker.

sen.j: 的絵（的の模様）には霞的と星的と色（得点）的の3種類がある。
sen.e: There are three matoe (pattern of a mato face) types: kasumi-mato (which literally means "mist target"), hoshi-mato (which literally means "star target"), and iro (also called tokuten) mato (which literally means "color [points] target").

There are three matoe (pattern of a mato face) types: Kasumi-mato (which literally means "mist target"), hoshi-mato (which literally means "star target"), and iro-mato (also referred as tokuten-mato, which literally means "color [points] target").

There are three matoe (pattern of a mato face) types: Kasumi-mato (which literally means "mist target"), hoshi-mato (which literally means "star target"), and iro-mato (also referred as tokuten-mato, which literally means "color [points] target").

sen.j: 競技規則には的中制の標的として霞的と星的が規定されているが、一般・中高生では通常霞的が使用される。
sen.e: The competition rules designate kasumi-mato and hoshi-mato as the target types for tekichu-sei (which literally means "accuracy system," in which a decision is made based on the number of hits) games, but kasumi-mato is generally used among adults, junior high, and senior high school students.

The competition rules designate kasumi-mato and hoshi-mato as the target types for tekichu-sei (which literally means "accuracy system," in which a decision is made based on the number of hits) games, but kasumi-mato is generally used among adults, junior high, and senior high school students.

sen.j: 大学弓道は全日本学生弓道連盟規約で星的の使用を定めている。
sen.e: Players in college and university kyudo are instructed to use hoshi-mato by the rules established by Student Kyudo Association.
Players in college and university kyudo are instructed to use hoshi-mato by the rules established by Student Kyudo Association.
Players in college and university kyudo are instructed to use hoshi-mato by the rules established by Student Kyudo Association.

sen.j: 実業団では得点的が使用される。
sen.e: Tokuten-mato is adopted in corporate kyudo.
Tokuten-mato is adopted in corporate kyudo.
Tokuten-mato is adopted in corporate kyudo.

sen.j: なお霞・星的を用いる通常の競技では的中の判定は「あたり」か「はずれ」のみであり、的のどこにあたろうと差はない（詳細は弓道競技方法参照）。
sen.e: In general kyudo competitions which use kasumi-mato or hoshi-mato, 'atari' (hit) and 'hazure' (miss) are the only decisions, no matter which area of the mato an arrow hits on (refer to the section of Competition in Kyudo for further details).

In general kyudo competitions which use kasumi-mato or hoshi-mato, 'atari' (hit) and 'hazure' (miss) are the only decisions, no matter which area of the mato an arrow hits on (refer to the section of Competition in Kyudo for further details).

In general kyudo competitions which use kasumi-mato or hoshi-mato, 'atari' (hit) and 'hazure' (miss) are the only decisions, no matter which area of the mato an arrow hits on (refer to the section of Competition in Kyudo for further details).

sen.j: 霞的
sen.e: Katsumi-mato

sen.j: 中心から順に中白（半径3.6cmの円）、1の黒（幅3.6cm）、2の白（幅3.0cm）、2の黒（幅1.5cm）、3の白（幅3.0cm）、外黒（幅3.3cm）の輪状に塗られているもの。
sen.e: This is a mato which has a nakashiro (which literally means "inner white," a circle with a radius of 3.6 centimeters) in the center, surrounded by ichi no kuro (which literally means "the first black," a ring with a width of 3.6 centimeters), followed by ni no shiro (which literally means "the second white," a ring with a width of 3.0 centimeters), ni no kuro (which literally means "the second black," a ring with a width of 1.5 centimeters), san no shiro (which literally means "the third white," a ring with a width of 3.0 centimeters), and a sotokuro (which literally means "outer black," a ring with a width of 3.3 centimeters).

This is a mato painted in the following manner from inner to outer; nakashiro (inner white circle with radius 3.6 centimeters), ichi no kuro (the first black ring with a width of 3.6 centimeters), ni no shiro (the second white ring with a width of 3.0 centimeters), ni no kuro (the second black ring with a width of 1.5 centimeters), san no shiro (the third white ring with a width of 3.0 centimeters), and sotokuro (outer black ring with a width of 3.3 centimeters).

This is a mato painted in the following manner from inner to outer; nakashiro (inner white circle with radius 3.6 centimeters), ichi no kuro (the first black ring with a width of 3.6 centimeters), ni no shiro (the second white ring with a width of 3.0 centimeters), ni no kuro (the second black ring with a width of 1.5 centimeters), san no shiro (the third white ring with a width of 3.0 centimeters), and sotokuro (outer black ring with a width of 3.3 centimeters).

sen.j: 本来は式正の的であるが、現在では大学弓道を除いて一般的に使われる。
sen.e: Although this type of mato was originally for formal ceremonies, this is now commonly used except for college and university kyudo.
Although this type of mato was originally for formal ceremonies, this is now commonly used except for college and university kyudo.

sen.j: 中心の白円は正鵠ともいい、『正鵠を得る』とは的の中心に的中することである（「正」「鵠」とも的の意）。
sen.e: The center white circle is also called seikoku, written as正鵠 in Japanese, and the phrase "seikoku o eru" (which literally means "obtain the seikoku," the equivalent of "hit the bull's-eye") represents hitting on the very center of a mato (both the Chinese characters '正' and '鵠' mean 'target').
sen.cmt: 正および鵠の漢字の意味についても言及されていますので、漢字を含めて訳出いたしました。
sen.e: The center white circle is also called seikoku (正鵠 in Japanese), and the phrase "seikoku o eru" (hit the bull's-eye) represents hitting on the very center of a mato (both '正' and '鵠' mean target).

sen.j: 白地の中心に半径6cmの黒丸を描いたもので、黒丸を特に星という。

sen.j: 『図星』の語源といわれる。

sen.j: 略儀の的であり、大学弓道の競技ではこれを用いる。

sen.j: 色は中心から金・緑・赤・白であり、得点は金10点、緑7点、赤5点、白3点である。
sen.e: Gold is in the center, followed by green, red, and white, and the assigned point of each color is 10 for gold, seven for green, five for red, and three for white.

sen.j: 遠的競技には的中制と得点制があるが、どちらも直径100cmの的を用いる。
sen.e: Enteki competitions consist of the tekichu-sei and the tokuten-sei (point system), and both the systems use a mato with a diameter of 100 centimeters.

sen.j: 的絵は、的中制は近的用霞的と同様の三重の黒輪、得点制はターゲットアーチェリーの配色と同様である（全体の寸法と配点は異なる）。
sen.e: The matoe pattern for the tekichu-sei is the one which has triple black rings, as well as kasumi-mato for kinteki, and the matoe for the tokuten-sei has the same color pattern as a target used in target archery (the size of a whole mato and the point allocation are different).

The matoe for tekichu-sei is triple black rings, the same pattern as kasumi-mato for kinteki, and the one for tokuten-sei is the same as target archery (the size of a whole mato and the point allocation are different).

sen.j: 射詰競射を行う場合は79cm（伝統的な半的に相当）または50cmの霞的が使用されることがある。
sen.e: A kasumi-mato whose diameter is 79 centimeters (this size is equivalent to a traditional han-mato [which literally means "half mato"]) or 50 centimeters is sometimes used in izume games.

sen.e: A kin-teki (which literally means "gold target") consists of a matowaku whose diameter is three sun (approximately 9.09 centimeters) and gold paper spread on it.

sen.j: 那須与一の屋島の戦いにちなみ、栃木県内各地の射会で用いられる。
sen.e: A sen-teki (which literally means "folding fan target") is used in shooting ceremonies held all over Tochigi Prefecture according to NASU no Yoichi's story of the Battle of Yashima.

sen.j: 扇子を90度に開いた形をしている。

sen.j: 弓道場にて行われる場合は半径36cmの扇形の枠に紙を貼ったものを用いる。
sen.e: When a ceremony is held in a kyudo hall, players use a folding fan-shaped frame whose radius is 36 centimeters with paper spread on it.

sen.j: 湖や川に向かって射る場合はブリキ製の大きめのものを竿に固定し、ボート上に高く立てて上向きに狙う。
sen.e: A little bigger mato made of tinplate is settled on a pole and it is held up high on a boat when players shoot arrows toward a lake or a river, and so they should aim upward.
A little bigger mato made of tinplate is settled on a pole and it is held up high on a boat when players shoot arrows toward a lake or a river, and so they should aim upward.
A little bigger mato made of tinplate is settled on a pole and it is held up high on a boat when players shoot arrows toward a lake or a river, and so they should aim upward.

sen.j: 花的
sen.e: Hana-mato
Hana-mato
Hana-mato

sen.j: 直径四寸五分 (数)で花札の12か月の図柄を的紙に描いた的。
sen.e: A hana-mato (which literally means "flower target") is a mato whose diameter is four sun and five bu (approximately 27.27 centimeters), and a picture of each month derived from hanafuda (Japanese floral playing cards) is painted on it.

A hana-mato (literally, "flower target") is a mato of four sun and five bu (approximately 27.27 centimeters), in diameter, with a matogami painted patterns of 12 month derived from hanafuda (Japanese floral playing cards).

A hana-mato (literally, "flower target") is a mato of four sun and five bu (approximately 27.27 centimeters), in diameter, with a matogami painted patterns of 12 month derived from hanafuda (Japanese floral playing cards).

sen.j: 地的
sen.e: Ji-mato
Ji-mato (地的)
sen.cmt: 読み不明の漢字を補足しました。
sen.e: Ji-mato (地的)

sen.j: 地面に円を描き的にし、放物線状に矢を射る。
sen.e: A ji-mato (which literally means "ground target") is a circle drawn on the ground, and players regard this as a mato and shoot arrows upward so they pass overhead describing a parabola.
A ji-mato (literally, "ground target") is a circle drawn on the ground, and players regard this as a mato and shoot arrows upward so they pass overhead describing a parabola.
A ji-mato (literally, "ground target") is a circle drawn on the ground, and players regard this as a mato and shoot arrows upward so they pass overhead describing a parabola.

sen.j: 射手から的は見えない。
sen.e: The shooters cannot see the mato.
The shooters cannot see the mato.
The shooters cannot see the mato.

sen.j: 広い安全な場所が必要。
sen.e: This needs a large safe place.
This needs a large safe place.
This needs a large safe place.

sen.j: 射流し
sen.e: Inagashi (the flight style of shooting in which the target is removed)
Inagashi (the flight style of shooting in which the target is removed)
Inagashi (the flight style of shooting in which the target is removed)

sen.j: 的は無い。
sen.e: It does not have actual mato.
It does not have actual mato.
It does not have actual mato.

sen.j: とにかく遠くまで矢を飛ばす。
sen.e: Players should shoot an arrow as far as they can.
Players should shoot an arrow as far as they can.
Players should shoot an arrow as far as they can.

sen.j: かなり広い安全な場所が必要。
sen.e: This needs a quite large and safe place.
This needs a quite large and safe place.
This needs a quite large and safe place.

sen.j: 大的
sen.e: O-mato
O-mato (literally, "big mato")
O-mato (literally, "big mato")

sen.j: 歩射の正式の的であり、現在の尺二的（小的）が普及するまで一般に使用された。
sen.e: An o-mato is a formal mato for busha (to shoot an arrow while walking), and this type had been commonly used until the current style of shaku-ni mato (also known as komato, the regular size mato for kinteki) became popular.

An o-mato is a formal mato for busha (to shoot an arrow while walking), and this type had been commonly used until the current style of shaku-ni mato (also known as komato, the regular size mato for kinteki) became popular.

An o-mato is a formal mato for busha (to shoot an arrow while walking), and this type had been commonly used until the current style of shaku-ni mato (also known as komato, the regular size mato for kinteki) became popular.

sen.j: 直径五尺二寸（約158cm）で的絵は霞的と同様である。
sen.e: Its diameter is five shaku and two sun (approximately 158 centimeters), and its matoe is the same as the matoe of kasumi-mato.
Its diameter is five shaku and two sun (approximately 158 centimeters), and its matoe is the same as that of kasumi-mato.
Its diameter is five shaku and two sun (approximately 158 centimeters), and its matoe is the same as that of kasumi-mato.

sen.j: 垂直に吊るして使用する。
sen.e: This should be hung vertically to be used.
This should be hung vertically to be used.
This should be hung vertically to be used.

sen.j: 武家の新年の弓射儀礼である的始などで使用され、現在でも小笠原流の儀式で用いられる。
sen.e: This was used for mato-hajime (the first shooting in the beginning of a year), which is the New Year's ceremony of shooting at a samurai family, and this is still used in ceremonies of the Ogasawara school.
This was used for mato-hajime, which is the New Year's ceremony of shooting at a samurai family, and this is still used in ceremonies of the Ogasawara school.
sen.cmt: 重複する補足を削除しました。
sen.e: This was used for mato-hajime, which is the New Year's ceremony of shooting at a samurai family, and this is still used in ceremonies of the Ogasawara school.

sen.j: 半的
sen.e: Han-mato
Han-mato
Han-mato

sen.j: 大的の半分の直径二尺六寸（約78.8cm）のもの。
sen.e: A han-mato is a mato whose diameter is two shaku and six sun (approximately 78.8 centimeters), which is a half of the diameter of an omato.
A han-mato is a mato whose diameter is two shaku and six sun (approximately 78.8 centimeters), which is a half of the diameter of an omato.
A han-mato is a mato whose diameter is two shaku and six sun (approximately 78.8 centimeters), which is a half of the diameter of an omato.

sen.j: その他、歩射の式では、三々九手挟式・振々式・草鹿式・円物等でそれぞれ独自の的が使用される。
sen.e: In addition, busha ceremonies such as San-San-Ku Tebasami Shiki (a solemn archery ceremony which was originally held on January 4), Buri-Buri Shiki (the ceremony which is usually held after San-San-Ku Tebasami Shiki or the yumi-hajime [the first shooting ceremony held on January 17]), Kusajishi Shiki (Japanese archery ritual), and Marumono (a simplified style shooting ceremony held for prayer) use their own style mato.
sen.cmt: 「円物」の説明は用語集で「a large round target」となっておりましたが、ここでは百々手式という儀式を簡略化した儀式のことを指しておりますので、これに従った訳を使用いたしました。参考URL：http://www.ogasawara-ryu.gr.jp/lessons/hosha/marumono/marumono.html
sen.e: In addition, busha ceremonies such as San-San-Ku Tebasami Shiki (a solemn archery ceremony which was originally held on January 4), Buri-Buri Shiki (the ceremony which is usually held after San-San-Ku Tebasami Shiki or the yumi-hajime [the first shooting ceremony held on January 17]), Kusajishi Shiki (Japanese archery ritual), and Marumono (a simplified style shooting ceremony held for prayer) use their own style mato.

In addition, busha ceremonies such as San-San-Ku Tebasami Shiki (a solemn archery ceremony which was originally held on January 4), Buri-Buri Shiki (the ceremony which is usually held after San-San-Ku Tebasami Shiki or the yumi-hajime [the first shooting ceremony held on January 17]), Kusajishi Shiki (Japanese archery ritual), and Marumono (a simplified style shooting ceremony held for prayer) use their own style mato.

sen.j: また「挟物」と言って、懐紙・履物・木の葉・土器・短刀など様々な物を串に挟んで的にすることもあった。
sen.e: Also, people sometimes make their mato by putting various things such as kaishi (Japanese tissue), a shoe, a leaf, earthenware, and a short sward between two sticks, and such mato are called 'hasamimono.'

Also, people sometimes make their mato by putting various things such as kaishi (Japanese tissue), a shoe, a leaf, earthenware, and a short sward between two sticks, and such mato are called 'hasamimono.'

Also, people sometimes make their mato by putting various things such as kaishi (Japanese tissue), a shoe, a leaf, earthenware, and a short sward between two sticks, and such mato are called 'hasamimono.'

sen.j: 「堅物射貫」と言い、本物の兜を的にすることもあった。
sen.e: A real warrior helmet is sometimes used as a mato, and this is called 'katamoto inuki.'
A real warrior helmet is sometimes used as a mato, and this is called 'katamoto inuki.'
A real warrior helmet is sometimes used as a mato, and this is called 'katamoto inuki.'
